Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation2: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat with my siblings lighting up with messages about the family holiday dinner. My sister had just sent a reminder: “Don’t forget, we need you there for the group photo and to help with the food!” I knew how much these gatherings meant to everyone, especially after Dad’s health scare last year. At the same time, my work laptop pinged with a new email. My team was waiting for my input on a project detail before they could move forward. The subject line read, “Urgent: Need your clarification ASAP.” I could almost feel the impatience behind the words. I wanted to be the reliable brother who showed up for family, but I was also expected to be the dependable colleague who never left the team hanging. My heart pounded as I weighed the disappointment in my sister’s voice against the frustration I’d hear from my manager if I delayed. I sat frozen, torn between two worlds, both needing me at the same moment.
